findings.title: Staking Incompatibility With Deflationary Tokens
findings.description: In the Gym Network protocol, the GymFarming contract is designed to take users’ assets and deliver rewards depending on their share. The contract uses safeTransfer()/safeTransferFrom() routines to transfer assets into or out of its pool, which may not work as expected with deflationary tokens.

findings.title: Possible MEV Issues For Reduced Return
findings.description: The `GymToken` protocol's `_swapReceivedGYM()` function is vulnerable to possible front-running attacks due to lack of slippage control, resulting in a smaller gain for users.

findings.title: Timely Reward Dissemination Upon Rate/Weight Changes
findings.description: The reward pools can be dynamically added via `add()` and the weights of supported pools can be adjusted via `set()`. When analyzing the pool weight update routine `set()`, we notice the need of timely invoking `massUpdatePools()` to update the reward distribution before the new pool weight becomes effective.

findings.title: Potential Reentrancy Risk in GymFarming
findings.description: The `checks-effects-interactions` principle is violated in the `withdraw()` function of `GymFarming`, allowing for potential reentrancy attacks.

findings.title: Trust Issue of Admin Keys
findings.description: The `Gym Network` protocol has a privileged `owner` account that plays a critical role in governing and regulating the protocol-wide operations (e.g., pool addition, reward adjustment, and parameter setting). It also has the privilege to control or govern the flow of assets among various protocol components.
